title: Collected Poems of Robert Service
description: "THE LOCKET"From out her shabby rain-coat pocketThe little Jew girl in the trainProduced a dinted silver locketWith pasted in it portraits twain."These are my parents, sir" she said;"Or were, for now I fear they're dead."I know to Belsen they were sent;I never heard of them again.So many were like that - they went,Our woeful quest was all in vain.I was in London with a friend,Or I, too, would have shared their end."They could have got away, I'm told,And joined me here in Marylebne,But Grannie was so sick and old,They could not leave her there alone.When they were seized she cried and cried:Thank God! 'Twas in her bed she died."How did they die? I cannot bearTo think of that - it crazes me.My mother was so sweet, so fair;My father handsome as you see . . .I'm sure no daughter ever hadMore lovely parents . . . Yes, it's sad."But for their loss I shall not grieve;I'll hug the hope they still survive;Oh, I must make myself believeSomehow, somewhere they're still alive. . . ."Well, that's my only souvenir,A locket stained with many a tear."
author: Robert W. Service
